Another month, another playroom rotation done ✔️
.
Here is a look at the playroom for my girls at ages:
21 months 
4.5 years 
6 years 
. 
You guys all know the deal with my rotations by now 😉 so if you have any other questions just pop them below and you know I’ll get to them soon 😘
.
.
.

node.text:
My eye was twitching Christmas morning with all the extra stuff in the playroom, so on Boxing Day I rotated the playroom to take out some of the old things and rotate in some of the new things! Anyone else feeling the need to do this at the moment? 🙈
.
It means the playroom stays tidy, the girls can engage with their new things, and then the ‘old’ things become ‘new’ again the next time I rotate them in to the room! 
.
We have a separate room in the house with a storage system that I store all the things that are ‘out’ of rotation. I’ve seen people do rotations with many different systems that work. Some people rotate out of tubs kept in the garage/store room. Some people have a single shelf of toys that they rotate things onto. Whatever works for you, I think rotating children’s resources is an amazing strategy to promote independent play 🙌🏻
.
So here’s our latest playroom video - let me know if there’s anything you’re wondering about! And Happy Holidays everyone! 🎄 I hope you guys all managed to make your Christmas magical no matter where you were ♥️
.
.

node.text:
At 18 months, here’s what a typical day looks like for us! Of course, this is just one day, and every day is different in its own way depending on what we do, but we generally stick to these timings...

7am: wake up, breastfeed, dressed 
8am: breakfast + shared reading. In the video, we ate breakfast earlier as we had swimming, but on a non-swimming day we eat around 8am. I read 3-4 books to the girls every morning over breakfast (I read while they eat), and it’s a lovely way to start the day off! 
9am: morning chores, activities + play 
11am: lunch (usually leftovers from previous nights dinner)
12pm: nap. Miss 18 months breastfeeds to sleep but can also put herself to sleep (when Daddy puts her to bed she just drifts off by herself)
2pm: wake up. Breastfeed 
2-3pm: afternoon snack 
3-4pm: play, afternoon activities 
4pm: start dinner prep. Miss 18 months potters around with me at the bench and around the playroom while I cook 
5pm: eat dinner. We eat as a family every night (except the weekend when it’s date night for hubs and I, so the girls eat at 5 and we eat later). Every night at the dinner table we each say something we were grateful for that day. Miss 18 months obviously can’t participate yet but the girls like to tell us what they think she would be grateful for if she could talk 😂
5.30-6pm: we send the girls outside and we tidy up from dinner.
6pm: bath
6.15pm: dressed in pjs in bedroom with dim lights + sing bedtime song (I made it up, we sing it every night right before I switch lights off)
6.20pm: lights out and breastfeed. She sometimes falls asleep while feeding, other times I feed her and then put her in her cot awake and she drifts off on her own 
Through the night: At 18 months she still generally wakes once a night for a breastfeed and some water (she’s always really thirsty when I go in and drinks a lot from her cup), but she does sleep through sometimes too. I still love feeding her and it doesn’t bother me to get up to feed her once in the night ❤️
.
.
.

#everydayplayhacks #toddlerplayideas #playhacks #playmatters #toddlerplayhacks #diymum #montessoridiy #toddlersensory #toddleractivitiesathome

node.title: • 18 MONTHS - A DAY IN THE LIFE •

node.text:
Video is up of the latest playroom set up! It’s about a 4 minute watch 😉 let me know here 👇🏻 if you have any questions about anything! 
.
We’re very lucky in our current house to have these three big open-plan rooms to dedicate to a playspace. We do still have a separate lounge and dining room. The playroom is right opposite the kitchen (you’ll see towards the end of the video). You DON’T need this much space to still have an effective place for your kids to play. We have lived in smaller houses and made do really well with the space we had (if you scroll waaaay back in my feed you might even see some playroom pics of our small playroom 😜)
.
You DON’T need all the resources we have to have an effective place for your kids to play. In fact, rotating toys is one of the biggest ways to get the most use, out of the least amount of toys! I share our set ups with you as I know it helps others with ideas for how to set up a multi-age space and because it helps you to narrow down what resources might be the best fit for your kids ❤️
.
The newest addition to this rotation is our @ilovemynook 😍🙌🏻 which the girls (and I) are all absolutely LOVING. I’ve been lusting over the nugget play couches (from the US) for aaaages and was so excited to hear that a family-run Aussie company has now made (what I think) is an even BETTER version 🙈 called the Nook. It’s a brilliant gross motor piece, as well as being a place to sit and relax comfortably in the room, or build large-scale forts and towers with 🙌🏻 because it’s modular it’s easy to move around and change up within the space, and it’s also a super easy pack up! Literally no draw-backs 😂
.
Almost everything in the room is from a store that’s afflinked in my bio - if you have any specific Q’s just comment below! 
.
.
.

node.text:
Here’s our latest playroom rotation! 
I’ll answer some frequently asked questions about the space below, and if you have more specific questions please comment them and I’ll get back to you! 
.
👉🏻 We try to rotate EVERY 2-3 WEEKS but lately it’s been more like every month 🙈
👉🏻 I rotate everything on the shelves, and some furniture. Usually I just move the big stuff around so it’s presented in a new/different way to spark new play 
👉🏻 I STORE all our resources in another room in @ikea_australia Trofast shelves - see my ‘storage’ story highlight (which will show you a progression of storage in our three previous houses) 
👉🏻 WHY ROTATE? It gets more life out of our current toys, it sparks more engagement and deeper play, and it allows me to keep up with their current interests and cater to their development in the things I choose to put out
👉🏻 I rotate Miss 15 months shelf toys more often - every 1-2 weeks. This is because she is developing rapidly at this point, and also because she gets bored more quickly 
👉🏻 ART AREA - see my ‘art space’ story highlights for more info 
👉🏻 READING CORNER - canopy is @hopeandjadeinteriors and the cushion is unfortunately not sold anymore 😭 the store closed down 
👉🏻 PLAY TABLE - our giant table in the back playspace is a hack by my husband - he added a piece of pine between two Ikea Trofast units to create a big play table! 
👉🏻 PADDED PLAYMATS - I’m always asked about these and today I’m so excited to offer you an exclusive DISCOUNT 😱 for 10% off family sized playmats from @mikro_australia - use code PLAYATHOMEMUMMY - valid for 1 week from today! 
.
Any more questions? Let me know! 👇🏻
.

While we were out here the other day I took a few videos of all of our outdoor spaces and I’ve put them all together here! Basically, we have: 👉🏻 Mud kitchen: we hacked this a few years ago from a Kmart outdoor storage bench! We added hinges to the lid, moved the base up to become the ‘bench’ part, cut a hole for a sink (the sink is a large dog bowl), and added a rail for hanging pans/utensils (rail was ikea). It’s a perfect height for little ones, and has suited the girls from about ages 1-3 years. Kmart no longer sell this bench but Ikea have a similar one called ‘applaro’ which I think would work the same 👉🏻 Sandpits: a sit-in sandpit which we got recently from eBay; an elevated sand pit which is a tuff tray on top of a cable reel; we use play sand from Bunnings (specially washed and graded) 👉🏻 Climbing gym: this one is a growplay set, but vuly and funky monkey also do these. This set has been INCREDIBLE for the girls gross motor skills and confidence, particularly Miss 4 - she has blossomed in her physical confidence since we got it! 👉🏻 Trampoline: ours is a Vuly ultra small 👉🏻 Cubby house: Kmart 👉🏻 Outdoor toys (trucks, animal figurines, sand toys) 👉🏻 Balance beams: Husband made them 👉🏻 Trikes/bikes/scooters (which we don’t have the space to ride in the backyard, but we have a great walking track right off our driveway!) .
The girls spend hours out here every day. One day I’d love to have a bigger (& prettier 🙈) garden, but we make do with what we have and the girls (especially Miss 13 months) all love being outside! .
.

node.text:
A couple of weeks ago we filmed an EPIC video for IGTV that shows you FIVE easy ways to play with water 💦 we had so much fun - it was an entire mornings worth of play 🙈😂 .
All these ideas are easy to do with almost any age! (Just watch the small parts for younger babes - maybe swap out for something bigger eg. Balls), as you can see all the girls (5.5, 4 and 13 months) had a blast with them all! .
I hope these ideas help the next time you’re stuck for an easy water play idea 😘
Here’s a summary:
1. BACKYARD BEACH - animal figurines, sand and blue water 💧 
2. POM POM WATER - food dye, Pom poms and scoops 🌈 (food dye won’t stain the skin or clothes when it’s dissolved in large amounts of water 
3. SPONGE STRIPS - cut up some (new) kitchen sponges and pair them with a tub of water and animal figurines - wash the animals!!
4. BALLOON BOB - fill some balloons with a little water, watch them bob around in a water tub and squish them in your hands!
5. COLOURED WATER AND FUNNELS - a bit of food dye and some funnels, cups and jugs is a super simple way to make water fun 🙌🏻
.
This was such a fun partnership with @bondsbumpsandbaby - if you try some, tag your own water play #playathomewithbonds 💦🌈
#bondspartner #bondswondermums .
.
.

node.text:
Live on my IGTV now! I’ve decided to do a video tour of the playroom and keep it on my IGTV so that it’s really easy to view and won’t disappear (like my stories do!) .
If you have any questions about the playroom please just comment them here and I will do my best to get back to everyone! I haven’t tagged everything in the tour because I wanted to keep it short + digestible for you .
FAQ:
👉🏻 HOW OFTEN TO ROTATE? I try to rotate fortnightly but recently I’ve been slack and haven’t. But I do rotate Miss 1’s things every week or two (I find the younger the child, the more frequently they need their things rotated to stay engaged)
👉🏻 WHY ROTATE? Because it increases engagement, keeps your toys fresh and utilised more often, and allows you to keep up with your child’s interests and development 👉🏻 DO YOU LEAVE SOME THINGS OUT ALL THE TIME? Yes. Things that get played with always, are always out (eg. The pikler, the blocks, the animal figurines 👉🏻 HOW IS YOUR PLAYROOM SO BIG? Our playroom is supposed to be the open plan living area of our house. It’s opposite the kitchen, so it’s in a very high traffic area of the house, which works perfectly. We opted to use this space for the playroom. However, we do also have a separate dining and lounge area. 👉🏻 WHERE DO YOU STORE THE THINGS THAT AREN’T IN THE PLAYROOM? They are stored in another room (my ‘storage area’) where I have shelving to suit all of this. See my ‘storage’ story highlight! 👉🏻 CAN I HAVE A PLAYROOM/ROTATE IF I ONLY HAVE A SMALL SPACE? Definitely. You may need to rotate more often though, and perhaps have a couple of different ‘nooks’ with small shelves in different areas of the house as opposed to all in one big room.
.
.
.

• SOAPY PLAY FOAM • 
Happy Mother’s Day everyone 🥰
I hope your days are filled with love from your littles ❤️ Just a short note from me today before I get back to enjoying my day with my little family......
......
Here’s a little something I prepared earlier for you 😉 it’s a full HOW-TO video for soapy play foam! Call it a Mother’s Day present from me to you 😜😂
.
Try to grab a minute or two for yourself this week while the kids play with this foamy goodness! .
@bondsbumpsandbaby @bondsaus #bondspartner #bondswondermum #bondswondercare .
.

node.text:
Unfiltered, unscripted, unprepared - watch the full IGTV video of just how a typical wall activity goes down with us! For this one, Miss almost-5 matched words to their matching diagraphs, while Miss 3 matched words to their beginning sound. This was quite a challenge for Miss almost-5 and we were working together for a while on it, so I’ve cut the video into a 5 minute clip! 
I wasn’t actually planning on uploading this video when I took it this morning, so trust me when I say this is not rehearsed in the slightest!
Sometimes I explicitly help, other times I stay silent to watch her figure it out. 
Miss 3 finishes first and she goes off to play while Miss almost-5 stays to keep working. They both really love these activities, I’m never ‘making’ them stay to do them, and if ever they didn’t want to continue I’d say that’s fine and offer to try again later! .
If you have 5 minutes and have ever wondered what it looks like to do one of these in our house, then I hope you enjoy it ☺️
.
Giant dot stickers are 50mm ones from eBay .
.

node.text:
• TODDLER PUZZLES • 

I find puzzles can be a really overwhelming toy to buy as there are so many varieties which suit such a wide range of ages, so it’s often tricky to know where to start for your toddler and what kind they might be into! 
.
👉🏻 We first introduced knobbed wooden or DIY puzzles around 12 months. Start with simple shapes, place photographs underneath which makes uncovering them a fun game even when they can’t quite get the pieces back into the right place! The circle size puzzle was a DIY and the wooden knobbed puzzle with the photos was from @kmartaus 
👉🏻 Next move to more complex shaped puzzles (eg. Animals, fruit, veg etc). You can start with the ones that have a matching picture underneath so your toddler can easily match the puzzle piece to the picture, then move to puzzles that have no picture underneath where your toddler is having to distinguish the shapes of each piece to determine where they fit. Our vegetable and animal knobbed puzzles are @classicworldtoys brand (there are lots of stockists), and we also have a fruit one the same.
👉🏻 Alternating the types of puzzles is important too. Some of our popular non-traditional puzzles are the Touch and Match Texture and Sensory puzzle, the @melissaanddougtoys beginner pattern blocks puzzle, and the @qtoysaustralia shape and size sorting board 
👉🏻 Size discrimination puzzles can be introduced once your toddler has shape puzzles down pat. Our green rectangular size discrimination puzzle is called the Montessori rectangle puzzle by @qtoysaustralia 
👉🏻 To introduce jigsaw puzzles I recommend starting with 2-piece puzzles. Our animal jigsaw is called puzzle duo by @djeco_toys , and our vehicles jigsaw is called the Lets Begin puzzle by @crocodilecreekaustralia 
👉🏻 Then you can start to move on to multiple piece jigsaw puzzles. I’d always recommend starting at smaller piece puzzles and working up from there, which I find happens quite quickly with toddlers! Our four piece seahorse jigsaw is called the progressive puzzle by @djeco_toys , and the 9 piece bugs jigsaw was from Kmart

node.text:
• BACKYARD BEACH • 

If you can’t get to the beach… bring the beach to you! 😆
.
My girls have been loving this one for years in the summertime. We’ve had some warm weather here lately so I set this beach up for playgroup the other day, and then yesterday still had all the sand and animals in the tub so I added some more water for the girls to have another play! 
.
You just need a big tub (though you could also set up a small scale beach in a small tub!), some sand, water, rocks, food dye and sea creatures 🌊
.
If you’re going to attempt this inside I 100% recommend putting a mat or towels underneath 😆 we use our waterproof @rudienudie_designs mat inside and outside because it soaks up the splashes and makes a comfy place for the girls to sit! You can use my code PLAY_AT_HOME10 for a discount- linked in my bio. The one they are on today is a large size (not jumbo), which is I think 1m x 1m
.
Our tub is an underbed storage container (Sistema brand) and is a great size for sensory play! We use play sand from @bunnings (it’s specially washed and sifted so it’s safe), and have an assortment of animal figurines. I generally set up the sand first, then place rocks next to the sand so it doesn’t run straight into the water. Fill the tub with water and add a few drops of blue food colouring! It doesn’t stain hands or clothes because it gets very diluted with the amount of water used! Add the animals and some leaves for seaweed and you’re good to go 👍🏻
.
It’s great for babies right through to big kids 🙌🏻 just watch that your rocks and figurines aren’t too small if you have a mouthing baby around (though check my stories to see that apparently my toddler still thinks licking the rocks is acceptable 🤦🏻‍♀️🤣)
.
This is a great one for:
👉🏻 DEVELOPING IMAGINATIVE PLAY SKILLS
👉🏻 COGNITIVE DEVELOPMENT - all sensory play is great for firing and wiring neurons in the brain 👍🏻
👉🏻 LANGUAGE DEVELOPMENT - naming animals, describing play 
👉🏻 SOCIAL/EMOTIONAL DEVELOPMENT - this is a great one to crack out with multiple kids at play dates/playgroups as they navigate play alongside and with each other 
.
.

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by E M M A • Baby Play + Beyond on August 31, 2021. May be an image of child and outdoors.

node.text:
• LIQUID CHALK PAINT • 

Perfect way to paint with a toddler without worrying about paint being flicked on the walls 😆
.
This is one we’ll be using a lot now the weather is starting to warm up ☀️🎨 and it’s a perfect way to use up all the little bits of chalk that are too small to draw with 👌🏻
.
Miss 2 loved painting with her ‘special paint’ on the pavement the other day - it goes on like water colour but dries looking just like chalk! (Swipe to see) 
.
All you need to do is:
👉🏻 Crush chalk (place in a zip lock bag and crush with mallet or hammer)
👉🏻 Add water 
.
The more chalk you use the brighter the paint will be when it dries, but we didn’t use much chalk at all and it still dries nice and colourful! 
.
Painting is wonderful for 
👉🏻 HAND EYE COORDINATION 
👉🏻 FINE MOTOR SKILLS 
👉🏻 CREATIVITY AND SELF EXPRESSION
👉🏻 COLOUR EXPLORATION 
And lots more 🥰 
.
Happy SPRING everyone 🌼🌿☀️
.
.
.

node.text:
• DIY 3 FRAME PLAY MIRROR • 

We made this hinged three frame mirror a couple of months ago for $30 all up and it was such an easy hack I wish we had done it years ago! 
. 
Mirrors are an awesome play resource for children of all ages - they can explore their own reflections, reflections of objects, symmetry, light and more! 
. 
To make it, you need:
👉🏻 3x lonsas mirrors from @ikea_australia $2 each 
👉🏻 3x ribba 21x30 frames from ikea $7 each 
👉🏻 4 hinges to attach the mirrors together (we found these at @bunnings , I can’t remember the exact name of them but they’re just cheap and simple silver hinges)
.
The mirrors fit perfectly inside the ribba frames, so I just slotted them straight in 🙌🏻 I left the perspex in front of the mirrors so that they will be safe even if a mirror cracks/smashes. Then just position the hinges where you want them and screw them into the frames! Done 💁🏻‍♀️
. 
We’ve been using this mirror at the art table a lot to explore reflections of drawings as well as sense of self, and Miss 2 really enjoyed seeing her block tower reflections as she built the other day! It promotes:
👉🏻 EARLY STEM SKILLS - reflection/symmetry 
👉🏻 STRONG SENSE OF SELF - exploring their own reflection is a way that toddlers and children come to know and love themselves ❤️
👉🏻 CREATIVITY/IMAGINATION - exploring the different ways of using the mirrors to create reflections 
.
.
.

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by E M M A • Baby Play + Beyond on August 25, 2021. May be an image of child and indoor.

node.text:
• SPRAY BOTTLE PICTURE REVEAL • 

If you own any of this magic water paper at home, I highly recommend taping it to a mirror/window, giving the toddler a spray bottle and letting them explore it with water sprays instead of a paintbrush 💦
.
This paper was from @kmartaus but you could also use the magic water calligraphy paper (we have some which we bought from eBay) - any paper that is activated by water will work! 
.
Miss 2 has been loving using the spray bottle to reveal the pictures, and wiping the mirror dry afterwards, then waiting for the paper to dry and do it all again 😂🙌🏻
.
The spray bottle is fantastic for:
👉🏻 FINE MOTOR SKILLS 
👉🏻 MUSCLE STRENGTH
👉🏻 HAND EYE COORDINATION - it’s actually really tricky to point the spray in the right direction whilst simultaneously spraying!
👉🏻BILATERAL COORDINATION 
.
This spray bottle was just from Woolworths, but you can buy small spray bottles from Kmart, dollar stores etc - Miss 2 has been using this one since she was about 14 months old to water the plants. She tucks it under one arm and pushes the trigger with the other! 
.
.

node.text:
• HANDY BLOCK • 

A great toddler practical life + fine motor DIY!
.
At 23 months old, Miss 2 was really focussed on this for a full week or two! My husband made it years ago for Miss 5 when she was 2, as she loved to help him build things. It was super easy to make and is still loved by all the girls! 
.
To make it, you need:
👉🏻 A rectangular block of wood (I think he used pine)
👉🏻 Some screw-in insert nuts (the bits that are embedded in the wood). He used task master brand, M6 size, from @bunnings 
👉🏻 Some bolts to screw inside the screw-in insert nuts. We used ones with an Alan key head (also M6 size), but you could use ones that require a screwdriver, or you could use an assortment to allow your kids to use different tools! 
. 
My husband just drilled some holes for the screw-in insert nuts to fit in, and sanded the wood down, and that was it! 
. 
This easy DIY is great for:
👉🏻Promoting FOCUS AND CONCENTRATION
👉🏻 Encouraging SELF CORRECTION AND INDEPENDENCE
👉🏻 Developing FINE MOTOR SKILLS AND MUSCLE TONE
👉🏻 Developing COORDINATION 
👉🏻 Promoting LANGUAGE DEVELOPMENT 
👉🏻 Developing PRACTICAL LIFE SKILLS 
. 
It also fosters a great sense of pride and accomplishment when they learn how to master different parts of the activity - first screwing the bolts in by hand, and then learning to tighten them with the Alan key 🙌🏻
.
.
.
.

node.text:
• JARS AND LIDS • 

Possibly the easiest toddler activity ever to set up 🙌🏻 and it was Miss 2’s favourite shelf activity for the month around her 2nd birthday back in May! 
.
Just grab some jars and containers from around the house - try and make sure the ones you pick have slightly different lids, eg. Screw top, push cap, big/small etc and set them out on a tray without their lids on
.
It’s a fantastic problem solving activity, can be done independently (just watch any lids that are small enough to be a choking hazard), and has so many other benefits too 🙌🏻
.
It promotes:
👉🏻 FINE MOTOR SKILL DEVELOPMENT - twisting and pushing lids
👉🏻 COGNITIVE DEVELOPMENT - problem solving to match the container to the correct lid gets those brains working
👉🏻 BILATERAL AND HAND-EYE COORDINATION - both hands working alongside each other to put the lids on, as well as the eyes working closely with the hands
👉🏻 PRACTICAL LIFE SKILLS & INDEPENDENCE - allows toddlers to practise the important skill of putting lids on and off 
👉🏻 LANGUAGE DEVELOPMENT - toddlers will often talk/engage in meaningful conversation about what they’re doing as they’re doing it. You can hear Miss 2 in this video commenting on the different things she’s finding out as she goes! 
.
.
.

node.text:
• DIGGER DIRT • 

Toddler sensory play at 26 months 🚜

A couple of weeks ago I made this HUGE tub of digger dirt to take to playgroup. Miss 2 wanted to help make it and afterwards played with this set up for a FULL SOLID HOUR 🙌🏻 the big girls played alongside her for almost as long too! We brought it to playgroup the next morning where it was enjoyed by all the other little people (as well as Miss 2 again, who spent almost the entire of playgroup at this tub 🤣)
. 
I have been making this every so often for the girls for years now, and love how simple it is to make and how much it is enjoyed by my kids. I follow *roughly* this recipe:
👉🏻 3 cups flour 
👉🏻 1 cup cocoa 
👉🏻 1/2 cup vegetable oil (or coconut oil etc)

The tub in this video is probably 3 or 4 times this recipe as I made a tub big enough for lots of kids to enjoy at playgroup, but the recipe above has always been enough for 1-2 of my kids to enjoy!
.
Tips:
👉🏻 Place a mat/tablecloth/sheet underneath. At the end, fold the mat and tip it back into the tub 👌🏻 we always use our @rudienudie_designs waterproof mats under sensory play - they’re machine washable 🙌🏻 code PLAY_AT_HOME10 gets you a discount - afflink in bio
👉🏻 This one won’t store indefinitely. You’ll be able to use it for a few days in a row if you keep it in a sealed container, but it is perishable
👉🏻 It is edible so safe to have around babies (if you’re worried about the flour, bake it on a tray for 20 mins before making)
👉🏻 You can change it up by adding any extras you like - bugs, figurines, fine motor tools etc. no need to stick to diggers 
.
Sensory play is wonderful for many reasons, some of which are: 
👉🏻 It provides SENSORY INPUT and STRENGTHENS NEURAL PATHWAYS
👉🏻 It assists with SENSORY INTEGRATION 
👉🏻 It promotes VOCABULARY 
👉🏻 It develops FINE MOTOR SKILLS 
👉🏻 It can help PICKY EATERS become familiar with different textures

node.text:
• TODDLER CHORES • 

Who else’s toddler is obsessed with daily chores? 🙋🏻‍♀️ being able to see what we often think of as ‘boring’ tasks through the eyes of a toddler has been one of the most magical parts of parenthood for me 💫  they have an amazing way of making ordinary tasks extraordinary 🥰
.
At 23 months, Miss 2 was right in the thick of practical life (and still is now!), and chores were something that brought her so much joy every day, and also occupied her for long lengths of time! 
Some chores that she did at 23 months (and still does now at 27 months) were:
👉🏻 Feeding the cat - her most favourite chore and a really lovely way for her to bond with our cat. I bought a scoop that is the correct serving size for the cats morning biscuits, so there’s no worry about her feeding too much/too little. 
👉🏻 Watering the plants - she has been doing this since about 14 months old with a spray bottle 
👉🏻 Putting clothes in the laundry basket 
👉🏻 Helping to hang and sort clean laundry 
👉🏻 Tidying up toys at pack up times - she loves having ‘jobs’ 😂 
👉🏻 Wiping up spills/messes 
👉🏻 Cleaning the mirrors (using water spray and a cloth) 
👉🏻 Vacuuming (with her tiny vacuum cleaner 🙈) 
👉🏻 Helping to unload the dishwasher/put cutlery away 
👉🏻 Helping to unpack groceries 
.
I believe involving children in chores from a young age is so beneficial! Here are some of the many benefits we have seen from giving children age-appropriate responsibilities:
👉🏻 It fosters a joy in the everyday 
👉🏻 It promotes independence 
👉🏻 It fosters a sense of personal responsibility 
👉🏻 It brings a sense of belonging to the family community 
👉🏻 It teaches life skills
👉🏻 It enhances coordination 
.
As the girls have grown, having an established routine of age appropriate responsibilities has also made things easier for me as they have grown in their independence and need very little assistance/direction for many tasks now at 5&6 years old! 
.

node.text:
• DIY TODDLER GEOBOARD • 

This was Miss 2 a few months ago at 23 months - she went through an obsession with our geoboard so I’m going to share with you today how to make one!
.
I made this years ago but it’s very simple and has been used repeatedly at our place. For toddlers, they’re focussed on learning to stretch the bands and loop them around the pins, and for preschool/older kids it’s a fantastic maths resource (making shapes). The big girls also love using it to create ‘enclosures’ for their animal figurines during imaginative play 😝
. 
You need a thick wooden chopping board, push pins, a hammer and a single nail that’s slightly thinner than your push pins. I used these plastic ones from Kmart so that they weren’t sharp. Mark out where you want your push pins with a ruler and pencil (you can space them as wide out or close together as you want), and then hammer the nail into each hole, each time pulling it back out so that you create guide holes for the push pins. If you don’t do this, you’ll break the plastic heads on your push pins by having to hammer too hard 😉 I learnt this the hard way! Once you’ve got guide holes in all your spots, gently hammer the push pins into them all
.
This resource is fantastic for:
👉🏻 FINE MOTOR SKILLS - it’s so tricky for little fingers to manipulate 
👉🏻 MUSCLE TONE AND STRENGTH - builds up the stamina of the muscles in fingers and hands 
👉🏻 HAND EYE COORDINATION - the eyes and hands work closely together 
👉🏻 LANGUAGE SKILLS - opens up lots of discussions - in this video you can hear Miss 23 months counting the pins! 
.
.
.

node.text:
• BABY FOUR ON THE WAY • 
You guessed it 🙈 we are so happy to announce that the reason we dropped off the face of the insta-sphere is the happiest one imaginable 🥰 we are expecting our FOURTH BABY GIRL 🎀 at the end of the year ✨ (yes, it’s another girl 🤣 We couldn’t be happier 🥰) 
.
We have three extremely excited big sisters who are eagerly anticipating the arrival of their little sister, who have been absolute troopers for the last few months while I was out of action with severe morning sickness. We are so incredibly lucky to be welcoming another little soul into our family 💕 
.
The last few months of sickness have been a huge struggle to get through. Without going into detail, my phone screen has been a big nausea/vomiting trigger (🤷🏻‍♀️ go figure, so is standing up, lying down, bending over or basically being awake in general 😩) so avoiding my phone has been a survival mechanism. I will share more about the last few months in my stories over the next few days/weeks, but for now I am so grateful to be feeling like myself again, to be able to focus on excitedly readying our family for this beautiful babe, and to be back here again after so long. I have really missed this community and being able to share with and be inspired by everyone in it ❤️
.
Thank you all for still being here to welcome us back after all this time (four months??!!! It’s the longest I’ve EVER been away from this account!) I am so excited to share more as our family continues to grow 💕
.
.
.

node.text:
• TRAVEL PLAY • 

Whether it be short or long car trips, long or short holidays, it’s always overwhelming trying to decide what to pack as ‘entertainment’ for the kids whilst trying to keep screens to a minimum (though no judgement if you use the screens ✌🏻)
.

We have done two family holidays in the last two months, which have involved 3 x 9hr (not including stops 😬) car trips, a series of holiday destinations including an Airbnb, a resort, and now staying with family at Gma and Gpas house - so here are a few of the things which have been great car and holiday kids activities for us so far! 
1. Sensory toys for the car - Kmart has a stack of cheap sensory toys which have helped to calm the girls and keep their hands busy on the long car trips! 
2. Balloons - these make fun sibling car games as well as great entertainment at your holiday destination!
3. Magnetic drawing boards for the car 🙌🏻 no paper or pens needed!
4. Magnetic games for the car - no lost pieces! 
5. Kids podcasts and audiostories for your big kids to listen to - Miss 6 could actually listen to these the entire trip long and I don’t think she’d need anything else 😂
6. Comforters/sleep cues help babies and toddlers to sleep better in the car (not exactly a play tip but so helpful for Miss 22 months!)
7. Playdough - it’s easy to bring, or make at your destination 👌🏻 and you can use simple kitchen utensils as tools! 
8. Kinetic sand - packs easy, bring along a fold up plastic kiddie pool and the mess is contained 🙌🏻
9. Plastic toys in a mesh bag double as beach AND bath toys - this bag is from ikea! 
10. Fold up inflatable water toys are easy to pack and fun for ALL ages 
11. Clipboards with paper, dot stickers and markers are great for toddlers and up 
12. Games like jenga double as family games and block play for the kids 
13. Sticker-by-numbers books are fun as well as lots of learning for your big kids on holiday! 
.
Feel free to share some of your travel play go-to’s because I’ll keep them up my sleeve for the trip home from Grandmas next week 😜
.
